												I originally purchased this game around the time that the sequel - Euro Truck Simulator 2 - was getting rave reviews. So why not buy the sequel? Because it was priced ten times more and - reviews aside - it seemed doubtful I would enjoy a game where I tediously drove a truck down highways avoiding traffic hauling cargo. At least, I thought,  the first game would give me an idea if I could even stomach the genre. And if it did, well only then would I consider paying the price for the sequel.I was surprised out how engaging this game was. Perhaps because it stood in such stark contrast to all my other driving games (the Need For Speed series, Burnout Paradise, and similar), but there was something very relaxing  and enjoyable about driving between the lanes, making a point not to speed (much) and slam into other cars. It was almost zenlike. The graphics might not be particularly impressive but they got the point across, and the AI of the other cars was pleasantly non-aggressive. Figuring out the best routes to take and what cargos to deliver was not particularly challenging but it was relaxing, and a welcome change from the ordinary.Sadly, that's not enough to sustain the game, at least not for me. Having advanced three tiers and played over twenty hours, the lack of variety is increasingly noticeable. All the highways and cities more or less look the same and the challenge is flat throughout. So while it was a wonderful ride up to this point, it wasn't enough to keep me playing until the nominal "end" of the simulation. However, it /was/ enough to get me interested in the sequel, which apparently adds extra content and gameplay. And since that was the whole point of my playing this game in the first place, I consider it time and money well spent.

												As a person who has been a flight simulator addict for going on three decades now...  ( I cut my teeth on a green screen IBM bootleg copy of Pilot trainer circa 1988 )  I have often been skeptical of the 'ground runners.'  Trains, racing cars and boats all have the same singular fundementle flaw on the virtual stage.  Primarily that no matter how much you REALLY want it to be true, you are NOT going to get a realistic perspective view of ... well ... ANYTHING.  Land and city scapes will always be a generic  reflection of what you just saw and are about to see again.  SO; having established my rational for skepticesm, what am I doing here?  To put it plainly.  I'm cheap and my entertainment budget can be bought.  In short for $20 I got the whole euro-truken-paint joben collection.  You should too, hopefully here is why....Pro # 1.It's Europe and there isn't a freken war going on.  Well okay...  Actually about 2 thirds of Europe.  Sans the Balkans half of Italy and 1/3 of Iberia.  If you like Scandanavia.  You are officially S.O.L.  Rather Ironic in fact, considering that no less than half of the riggs you use in this series are models made in either Sweden or Norway.  Back to the point.  See something of the great old country without having to shoot it, dog fight over it or deal with Hitler or Napoleon.# 2. Beautifully simple.  Elegantly addictive.  I honestly went into this game with little if any knowledge of truck driving and after 6 hours that passed by like 30 minutes, I not only know something about the actual life style, I can also add that it was fun doing something curiously different than trying to beat a bunch of crazies to a finish line.The one and only con I can come up with, is that the technology of it's day DOES let it down somewhat.  However; as I mentioned before I got the collection so I expect the second edition to be a bit more advanced.  Not only graphic wise but the over all control experience.  This first one is the best to learn on.  If you can get comfy with this one then you can graduate to more complicated challenges.Jim

												I really enjoy this game, even though people may think it's boring to keep driving back and fourth to different cities to only drop off cargoes in order to gain more money. Although there is less cities to drive to, I still enjoy it. I love the feeling to be able to drive properly, and have played 20 hours within 2 days due to being obsessed. I'm not saying the game is perfect, hell, the second game might not even be perfect (can't buy it since I have a Mac) however it still is fun.I am quite big on graphics, and I have to admit this isn't so bad. The trucks/cars both look great and so does the interior of the trucks. You can either drive on manual or automatic which adds realism, and so does the various types of weather, time, and the rules of the road. Sound doesn't seem to be much of a problem, it has realistic car, weather, truck and engine noises.Having to deliver more and more in order to gain more money, does take a lot of time. But this leads to the game being more addictive and actually worth it. However, if driving back and forth for a while isn't really your thing, this can become a problem, though I ensure it wont be when you actually try it out, and even better, unlock more places.One thing that has annoyed me while driving around on here is how stupid the other drivers are. They either go the wrong way, beep at me when I am not doing anything wrong, and/or randomly brake when there was no need to which leads me into hitting them, which leads to me having to pay for hitting them. Adding pedestrians or animals would also be something which would make the game better (no I do not want to run them over)Another thing is how the cities are extremely small, and only have up to 5-6 roads, which is bad for when you want to explore other places other than the highway. The sound is good, but not so great. It sounds like I'm driving ontop of the truck rather than inside (might be because the windows are always open for some reason) and the radio does not sound like it's actually coming out of a radio in the truck.Honestly, I love this game even though it has some flaws which I have to live with, however those are probably fixed in ETS2. I recommend this game if you either have a older computer, have a Mac and cannot buy the second one (which is my case) or have a few cash left or is low on cash to spend it on this. An overall 6/10 from me.

												This game is fun and a great starting point if you want to get into SCS's Truck sim games as its quite smaller than ETS2 and has a few less features to worry about, this game is very similar to ETS2 with a few differences, for example in ETS2 you have to save up or take a loan to get your first truck but in this one you are made to buy your very first truck straight away and the way you take jobs is set differently too.I have this game on my Tablet PC running a 1.66ghz atom processor and it runs smoothly with no visible issues, therefore it would be the better game to grab if you are wanting something with very low specifications for journeys on public transport or if you are a passenger on a road trip, there are a few flaws with the game but nothing thats too game breaking, if you have played ETS2 or even Scania truck driver simulator this game will feel outdated and primitive, however if you are looking to get into the series you cant go wrong with getting this game as part of the SCS deluxe package as you will get alot more value for your money.all in all this game has aged very well and even to this days standards looks like a very well made indie game however you will feel dissapointed if you come from one of the newer games in the series, i will not go as far as to label this game as a high quality game but it is for the most part a decent playable game that can keep you going for endless ammounts of playing as you strive to work for bigger jobs or better trucks.If you are looking for a highly detailed yet smoothly running truck simulator you cannot go wrong with this title, however if you want a more up to date feel with even better graphics, go for ETS2. if you cannot decide go for the deluxe bundle as you will get 5 titles and a whole bunch of DLC for ETS2.7/10

The driving feels far too heavy to be enjoyable, even for a simulator, and there are so, so many bugs in the physics engine and the AI's control of their vehicles for me to avoid running out of money while transporting goods.The AI change lanes as fast as the cars on the freeways in GTA: San Andreas did - i.e. faster than your lumbering starter truck could ever hope to. 												As a casual player who doesn't really play casual games, I can only think of a single reason to play such a game: The Scenery. But this game has none.  Everthing seems the just same. Details are poorer than driving games 10 years older than that. Different places are hardly distinuishable, cities are really sparse (ie, in Switzerland there is only Bern, in Italy just Rome and Milan), and when you visit them, they just look like small villages in the middle of nowhere. Perhaps that's what a truck driver sees, visiting only the industrial areas of citiies, but, even so, not once I experienced the magnificence of observing a really large city from a distance.Music is inexistent; still no radio stations available after 4 hours of playtime, so I had to open an external music player to listen to while driving. Controls are not satisfying either (quite clumpsy), but perhaps I'm using the wrong truck.To give you an idea about "role playing" part, I have to repeatedly drive between Bern and Rome about 15 times, just to unlock a new area, in the hope of seeing something barely different.From the trading aspect, there are no real choices: Just sort the missions and take the one that gives the most money. 												Hearing about the wonders that the sequel to this game had, I wanted to see what the roots were. Having a outdated laptop that can't run much, the older game runs like gold on any computer of the recent 4 years or more. I experience some drops in frame rate here or there but not enough to say it is a problem.The game itself is quite simple. Drive from here to there. Pick your haul and your destination. It is a simple concept that can have you sink hours into the game. Since this was the first of its kind, there number of options is limited and few compared to the sequel. You can't make your own company, and there is no RPG style leveling system. You just haul to get enough cash to upgrade your rig.For what the game is, I adore it alot and plan to keep playing it. There is a steep curve in progress from your starting rig to a better one, but aside from that there is plenty of things to do. I can almost compare this to my time spent on Eve Online as a freighter for ore and other goods. I even play some Southern Rock on my ipod while I play this game. This is a game that you want to kill time with. Is ETS2 better? Well, of course it is a sequel. However, if you want a simpler version or you have a sub-par gaming computer, buy this. If you are up for a more complex and demanding game, buy the sequel.

												It's not terrible, but it does lack the polish and refinement that a good game should have. Controllers are not turned on by default, and need tweaking to the settings to get working smoothly. The mini-map is awkward to follow with symbols regularly being obscured. The tutorial, for instance, instructs you to navigate to a symbol on the map which you won't be able to see, as it is hidden under another symbol. Warnings and dialog boxes are enormous and obscure your view, and menus can't be controlled with a controller or keyboard, only with the mouse. More importantly, the game-world lacks variety.Cheers to the developers for trying something out that is different and potentially quite enjoyable, but I wouldn't actually pay money for what feels like an unfinished "concept" game.
